texts.shortText: Unmistakable air-breathing isopod found abundantly on the upper intertidal levels of rocky shores and distinguished by the elongate paired ‘horns’ arising from the dorsal surface of each thoracic segment. The horns are typically much longer in adults and in males relative to females. Abdomen clearly segmented and uropods each with a single short ramus (as opposed to the pair of elongate rami in Ligia species, which share the same habitat).

Global: Southern Africa and St Paul and Amsterdam Islands (those outlying populations probably represent a distinct species).

Local/Regional: Namibia to about Knysna.

Very common around the drift line of rocky shores wherever drift kelp is cast ashore, where they co-occur with the even more abundant Ligia species. Feed on drift kelp and other algae, and may also scavenge on dead animals. Most active at night, but also on cloudy days, moving down to the shore to feed and back above the high water mark to shelter during heat of the day. May migrate in formidable numbers.
Mainly kelp, but also other drift algae and organic debris.
As with all isopods the eggs are retained within a marsupial pouch between the walking legs of females and hatch into fully-developed juveniles.

The only member of the family Detonidae in South Africa and unlikely to be confused with other species due to the unusual dorsal ‘horns’. The populations on St Paul and Amsterdam Islands have dorsal spikes on the abdominal segments as well and thus are almost certainly a different species. Often found together with other air-breathing isopods of the genus Ligia, which lack horns and have long uropods with two elongate branches. Recent but still unpublished genetic data suggest that Deto populations from the west and south coasts in fact represent two separate species.

Chilton, C (1915). Deto, a Subantarctic genus of terrestrial Isopoda. Zoological Journal of the Linnean Society, 32(219), 435–456.

Glazier, DS, Clusella-Trullas, S, & Terblanche, JS (2016). Sexual dimorphism and physiological correlates of horn length in a South African isopod crustacean. Journal of Zoology, 300(2), 99–110.
